results.title: Sheep on show
results.brief_description: A special sheep show was held in Melbourne at the time of the Olympic Games, and to further publicise the wool industry a large party of foreign journalists were taken on a tour of sheep studs which included Canberra, central Queensland, Alice Springs and Broken Hill. The film concludes with the Wool Fashion Award of 1957.

results.title: Sheep in the desert
results.brief_description: Shows how sheep can be raised successfully in low rainfall areas of Australia. It concentrates on one large station, Wilgena, nearly two million acres in extent and carrying 45,000 sheep. This station is self supporting, generating its own power and light, and is fitted with the most modern appliances. It produces sheep of fine quality and is entirely mechanised, the sheep being rounded up by men on motor bikes. In an area with an average rainfall of only 5 and a half inches, much needed water is supplied by sub-artesian bores. Vermin-proof fences check pasture destruction by rabbits and stock losses by dingoes.

results.title: The Shearing table
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the shearing of sheep using mechanical shears. Old blad3 shears are compared with modern mechanical shears and both are seen in operation. A shearing table is examined, demonstrating the ease and comfort of a shearer using the table. Demonstrates the operation of a chain system of shearing in which a number of tables move around in a circle, each shearer working on a particular part of the sheep.

results.title: RAAF Record. Newsreel No. 07
results.creator_credit: Stanley Brogden and Australia. Royal Australian Air Force. Directorate of Public Relations
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine newsreel includes the following: 1. The RAAF flight in the Antarctic use Canadian “Beaver” aircraft. 2. RAAF personnel are trained by firemen in Melbourne. 3. The Lockheed Hercules transport. 4. The “Jindivik” pilotless aircraft, designed and built in Australia, shown in flight at Woomera range.

results.title: The Blowfly menace
results.creator_credit: A. C. McKay BVSc and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: For farmers and graziers this study of the life-cycle of the green blowfly and other flies associated with blowfly strike in sheep, and demonstrations of various methods of control, should prove both useful and interesting.

results.title: Before production begins
results.brief_description: The story of the birth of a new Holden car, from an artist’s conception, through the modelling of small and full scale models, to the making of the first prototype model. From the hundreds of scale drawings, skilled craftsmen create by hand, the hundreds of engine and body components of the prototype. Laboratory and road tests of components and the completed prototype ensue that every section of the car conforms to rigid engineering specifications. Only after all this preliminary work can mass production begin on a new model Holden car.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains great footage of a trip to Japan, including urban scenes, Japanese cars, visits to temples and socialising with Japanese locals.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 aeroplanes on the tarmac
00:00:14:00 view from the plane as it takes off, including the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:01:32:00 coastline from the plane
00:01:45:00 view from the plane, Bali International Airport Ngurah Rai
00:02:20:00 scenes in Japan
00:03:00:00 feeding the deer, probably at Nara
00:03:30:00 Tōdai-ji, Nara (temple complex)
00:04:05:00 Bishamonten statue, Tōdai-ji, Nara
00:04:45:00 in the forest and visiting temples
00:05:41:00 a cute Japanese toddler in pink overalls
00:07:35:00 driving through city streets, views from the window of a bus
00:08:55:00 groups of Japanese schoolchildren having their photo taken at a temple
00:11:17:00 a fish pond with a waterfall (Ninomaru Garden and pond, Nijo Castle, Kyoto)
00:11:35:00 people viewing didactic map of Nijo Castle complex, Kyoto
00:14:00:00 cable car on a busy city street
00:15:08:00 neon sign ‘Matsushita Electric’
00:17:53:00 orderly city streets filled with traffic
00:20:10:00 View of Mt Fuji
00:20:55:00 close-ups of group of Japanese friends at dinner, all laughing and pulling faces at the camera
00:22:43:00 bright neon billboards at night
00:24:00:00 Coca-Cola billboard
00:25:02:00 view of city buildings from a plane landing
00:26:00:00 views across the harbour of a city (possibly Hong Kong)
00:28:34:00 double decker cable cars covered in advertising

results.title: Bushfire: our summer fate
results.brief_description: Shows how a bushfire in the Blue Mountains on 6 December 1977 caused the death of one person, 70 homes to be destroyed and the evacuation of thousands all in a space of five hours and similarly how the bushfire of summer 1967 in Hobart killed 62 people and destroyed upto 1000 homes and 130 major buildings. Includes a report by scientist David Ellyards on how, where and why bushfires start in Australia followed up by how to prevent death and destruction due to bushfires.

Includes a report by scientist David Ellyards on how, where and why bushfires start in Australia followed up by how to prevent death and destruction due to bushfires.

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This short film shows the family swimming and boating.

Selected highlghts list:
00:00:02:00 family members swimming in the shallows of a river among logs
00:00:50:00 boats moored in a sheltered spot including the ‘Shenandoah’ which the family is boarding

group_siblings.title: [Donald Duck in Matching Tricks; The Charging Bull]
